newsitem.title: USA: Orange County bankruptcy trial enters final stage.
newsitem.headline: Orange County bankruptcy trial enters final stage.

text.p: Jurors in the bankruptcy-related trial of former Orange County, Calif., assistant treasurer Matthew Raabe will return to court next week to hear closing arguments as attorneys wrap up the case.
Jurors are scheduled on April 29 to hear final arguments in Santa Ana from both the prosecution and the defense before beginning their deliberations.
The prosecution alleges that Raabe helped to divert nearly $90 million in interest earnings owed to cities, schools and special districts that invested in the county-run portfolio.
Raabe's attorney, Gary Pohlson, called six defense witnesses earlier this week. Most of them described Raabe was a loyal and hard-working county employee.
Orange County filed for bankruptcy in December 1994 after sustaining losses of more than $1.6 billion on risky investments. The county emerged from bankruptcy last June.
Raabe was one of several Orange County officials to face charges following the bankruptcy.
In April 1995, former Orange County Treasurer Robert Citron pleaded guilty to six felonies for his role in the crisis.
A judge last November ordered him to spend a year in jail and pay a $100,000 fine, but Citron was later assigned to a community work program instead of jail.
Citron claims that Raabe was the "mastermind" behind a scheme to divert the interest earnings.
Last October, a judge sentenced former Orange County budget director Ronald Rubino to probation for charges stemming from the investment crisis.
